newsitem.title: BOLIVIA: Bolivia postpones tin smelter tender.
newsitem.headline: Bolivia postpones tin smelter tender.

text.p: Bolivia's government Wednesday called off its planned privatization of the Empresa Metalurgica Vinto tin smelter due to problems caused by a labor dispute and said it will call a new tender next week.
Vinto's privatization was planned for Thursday, but Capitalization Secretary Edgar Saravia said "conditions are not right" and called off the sale process.
Saravia told reporters that Brazil's Paranapanema, one of the companies shortlisted to buy Vinto, withdrew its offer earlier in the day due to labor unrest.
Two others, Australia's Renison Goldfields Consolidated Ltd and Glencore International of Switzerland, requested changes in the terms which led the government to halt the process.
About 200 jobless workers occupied the Mount Posokini zone of Huanuni 10 days ago calling for small mine concessions.
"This sort of attitude definitely frightens those who were interested in (buying) Vinto," Mining Secretary Teddy Cuentas told reporters earlier in the day.
Nevertheless, Cuentas said the Huanuni mine, 170 miles (270 km) south of La Paz, was producing normally.
Saravia said the new tender will include all the necessary changes needed to ensure the sale will go through.
Apart from its Bolivian supplies from state-owned mines and small producers, Vinto also tolls tin concentrates from Peru's Minsur into metal.

The government plans to award 50 percent of Vinto to private hands, as well as administrative control. The other shares will be used to finance a new private pension fund system and divided among adult Bolivian citizens.
The winner of the tender will also be awarded control of the government's Huanuni and Colquiri tin mines.
